problems.title: Furniture Store
problems.statementHtml:
On the website of a company that manufactures and sells furniture, customers can order nn different models of sofas, numbered from 11 to nn. Each sofa has a unique price; the price of the ii-th sofa is denoted by aiai.

Every customer who visits the website has their own budget mm, which they are willing to spend on a sofa. When they look through the list of sofa models, they search for the first sofa that costs no more than mm and orders it. If there are no such sofas, then the client leaves the website without ordering anything.

The company aims to identify which sofas will never be ordered. Your task is to determine the models such that there is no such budget mm that a customer will order this particular model.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤10001≤t≤1000) — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (1≤n≤1001≤n≤100).

The second line contains nn distinct integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤1001≤ai≤100).
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, provide the answer in this format: on the first line, print a single integer kk — the number of models that cannot be ordered. On the second line, print exactly kk integers in ascending order, representing the indices of the models that cannot be ordered.

problems.title: Games
problems.statementHtml:
Alice and Bob are planning to play an online game together but haven't decided on which one yet. Alice has a list of nn games she enjoys: a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an. Bob, on the other hand, has a list of mm games he likes: b1,b2,…,bmb1,b2,…,bm. They share at least one game in common between their lists.

To choose a game, they take turns suggesting games from their lists. Alice begins by suggesting one of her favorite games. If Bob likes it, they play that game. If not, Bob suggests one of his favorite games. If Alice likes it, they play that game. This alternating process continues, with Alice and Bob each suggesting games from their lists in turn, ensuring that no game is suggested more than once.

Your task is to calculate the maximum possible number of suggestions they will make while choosing which game to play.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤10001≤t≤1000) — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and mm (1≤n,m≤1001≤n,m≤100).

The second line contains nn integers a1<a2<⋯<ana1<a2<⋯<an (1≤ai≤1001≤ai≤100).

The third line contains mm integers b1<b2<⋯<bmb1<b2<⋯<bm (1≤bi≤1001≤bi≤100).

Arrays aa and bb contain at least one common integer.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, print a single integer — the maximum possible number of suggestions they will make while choosing which game to play.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, the maximum number of suggestions is 33. It is achieved as follows:

  • Alice suggests game 11, but Bob does not like it;
  • Bob suggests game 55, but Alice does not like it;
  • Alice suggests game 22, which Bob likes, and they go to play that game.

In the second test case, Alice can only suggest game 55, which Bob likes, so they will immediately go to play it.

In the third test case, the maximum number of suggestions is 44. It is achieved as follows:

  • Alice suggests game 77, but Bob does not like it;
  • Bob suggests game 66, but Alice does not like it;
  • Alice suggests game 11, but Bob does not like it;
  • Bob suggests game 44, which Alice likes, and they go to play it.

problems.title: Minimum on Subarrays
problems.statementHtml:
There is a variable sumsum, which is initially equal to 00.

There is also a data structure that can perform the following operations:

The operations popback, popfront, and min cannot be applied to an empty structure!

Using this structure, you would like to be able to find the sum of the minimums of all non-empty subarrays of an array aa of nn elements.

More formally, your task is to find a sequence of no more than n⋅(n+2)n⋅(n+2) commands such that after all operations, the variable sumsum will be equal to ∑0≤l≤r<nmin(a[l],…,a[r])∑0≤l≤r<nmin(a[l],…,a[r]) for any possible array aa.
problems.inputSpecHtml: The first line contains a single integer nn (1≤n≤5001≤n≤500) — the number of elements in the array.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
Output kk (1≤k≤n⋅(n+2)1≤k≤n⋅(n+2)) commands. Each command must be one of the following five lines:

  • "pushback a[i]", where ii — a number from 00 to n−1n−1
  • "pushfront a[i]", where ii — a number from 00 to n−1n−1
  • "popback"
  • "popfront"
  • "min"

If there are multiple valid answers, output any.

samples.output:
6
pushfront a[1]
min
pushback a[0]
min
popfront
min

problems.title: Avoid Minimums
problems.statementHtml:
You are given an integer array a1,a2,a3,…,ana1,a2,a3,…,an. Your task is to make all elements of aa equal. In order to do it, you can perform the following operation at most kk times:

What is the maximum number of coins you can earn among all possible ways to make the array equal?
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains one integer tt (1≤t≤10001≤t≤1000) — the number of test cases. Next, tt cases follow (all cases are independent).

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and kk (2≤n≤3⋅1052≤n≤3⋅105; 1≤k≤10121≤k≤1012) — the size of array aa and the maximum number of operations you can perform.

The second line contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤1091≤ai≤109) — the array itself.

It's guaranteed that the total sum of nn over all test cases doesn't exceed 3⋅1053⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, if it's impossible to make all elements equal, print −1−1. Otherwise, print the maximum number of coins you can earn while making all elements equal.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, you need at least 1717 operations to make all elements equal (or to get the array [10,10,10][10,10,10]).

In the second test case, you can, for example, increase a3=4a3=4 to 1010, then increase a1=6a1=6 to 1010, after that increase a4=9a4=9 to 1010 and, finally, a2=2a2=2 to 1010. You'll perform 1919 operations and earn (10−4)+(10−6)+(10−9)=11(10−4)+(10−6)+(10−9)=11 coins in total, since increasing the a2a2 from 22 to 1010 won't give you any coins.

In the third test case, you can leave the array unchanged or make all elements equal to 88 — both strategies will give you 00 coins.

problems.title: Perfect Cut
problems.statementHtml:
You are given a string ss consisting of characters 0, 1, and/or ?.

Let's call a binary (consisting of 0 and/or 1) string perfect if you can cut the string into two non-empty parts: a prefix aa and the suffix bb, such that ai≥biai≥bi for each ii from 11 to min(|a|,|b|)min(|a|,|b|).

Your task is to calculate the number of ways to replace all the question marks (independently) with zeros and ones so that the resulting string is perfect mod. Two ways are considered different if there exists at least one position that has different characters in these two ways. Since the answer can be large, print it modulo 998244353998244353.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104) — the number of test cases.

The only line of each test case contains a string ss (2≤|s|≤2⋅1052≤|s|≤2⋅105), consisting of characters 0, 1, and/or ?.

Additional constraint on the input: the sum of the lengths of the strings ss over all test cases doesn't exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, print a single integer — the number of ways to replace all the question marks (independently) with zeros and ones so that the resulting string is perfect, taken modulo 998244353998244353.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, the string 001 can be split into a prefix of length 11 and a suffix of length 22.

In the fourth test case, the following strings can be obtained:

  • The string 11010, which can be split into a prefix of length 22 and a suffix of length 33;
  • The string 11000, which can be split into a prefix of length 44 and a suffix of length 11.

problems.title: Array Reduction
problems.statementHtml:
You are given an array aa containing nn integers.

In one operation, you can choose some elements from this array and remove them. However, the elements you choose must meet one of the following conditions:

Note that if you choose only 11 element to remove, it automatically meets these conditions.

For example, if a={1,2,1,1,3}a={1,2,1,1,3}, some of the possible elements you can remove in one operation are:

However, you cannot choose the 22-nd, the 33-rd and the 44-th element because the 22-nd element is not equal to the 44-th, but the 33-rd element is equal to the 44-th.

For each xx from 00 to n−1n−1, you have to calculate the minimum number of operations required to decrease the size of the array to exactly xx.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains one integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104) — the number of test cases.

Each test case consists of two lines:

  • the first line contains one integer nn (1≤n≤3⋅1051≤n≤3⋅105) — the size of the array;
  • the second line contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤n1≤ai≤n) — the array itself.

Additional constraint on the input: the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 3⋅1053⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, print nn integers c0,c1,…,cn−1c0,c1,…,cn−1, where cici is the minimum number of operations required to reduce the size of the array to exactly ii.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first example, the answer can be obtained as follows:

  • c0=3c0=3: remove a8,a9,a10,a11a8,a9,a10,a11; then remove a1,a2,a3,a4a1,a2,a3,a4; then remove a5,a6,a7a5,a6,a7;
  • c1=3c1=3: remove a8,a9,a10,a11a8,a9,a10,a11; then remove a1,a2,a3,a4a1,a2,a3,a4; then remove a5,a6a5,a6;
  • c2=2c2=2: remove a7,a8,a9,a10,a11a7,a8,a9,a10,a11; then remove a1,a2,a3,a4a1,a2,a3,a4;
  • c3=2c3=2: remove a7,a8,a9,a10,a11a7,a8,a9,a10,a11; then remove a1,a2,a3a1,a2,a3;
  • c4=2c4=2: remove a7,a8,a9,a10,a11a7,a8,a9,a10,a11; then remove a1,a2a1,a2;
  • c5=1c5=1: remove a1,a7,a8,a9,a10,a11a1,a7,a8,a9,a10,a11;
  • c6=1c6=1: remove a7,a8,a9,a10,a11a7,a8,a9,a10,a11;
  • c7=1c7=1: remove a1,a2,a3,a4a1,a2,a3,a4;
  • c8=1c8=1: remove a1,a2,a3a1,a2,a3;
  • c9=1c9=1: remove a1,a2a1,a2;
  • c10=1c10=1: remove a7a7;

problems.title: Good Robot Paths
problems.statementHtml:
On a Cartesian plane, there are n distinct points painted black, while all other points are painted white. Each black point has integer coordinates.

There is also a robot that can move one unit in any of the directions 'U' (up), 'D' (down), 'L' (left), or 'R' (right) with a single command.

A path of the robot from point p1 to point p2 is a sequence of commands such that if the robot, starting at point p1, executes this sequence, it will arrive at point p2.

The shortest path of the robot from point p1 to point p2 is a path whose sequence consists of the minimum possible number of commands.

You need to count the number of pairs of points pi, pj (i≠j) such that for this pair of points the following condition holds:

All points with integer coordinates on any shortest path of the robot from point pi to point pj are painted black.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t (1≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer n (1≤n≤5⋅105) — the number of points painted black.

The next n lines of each test case contain two integers xi,yi (−109≤xi,yi≤109) — the coordinates of point pi. All points are pairwise distinct.

It is guaranteed that the sum of n across all test cases does not exceed 5⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a single integer — the answer to the problem.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, there are 16 suitable pairs of points:

  • p1,p2
  • p1,p3
  • p1,p4
  • p1,p5
  • p2,p1
  • p2,p3
  • p2,p4
  • p2,p5
  • p3,p1
  • p3,p2
  • p3,p4
  • p4,p1
  • p4,p2
  • p4,p3
  • p5,p1
  • p5,p2

problems.title: Merging Vertices in a Graph
problems.statementHtml:
You are given an undirected graph, initially containing nn vertices and mm edges. You can perform the following operation on this graph:

This operation can be performed any number of times until there exists a vertex in the graph that is directly connected by edges to all other vertices. As soon as such a vertex appears, the process ends. Additionally, if such a vertex already exists in the graph initially, no operations can be performed.

Your task is to count the minimum and maximum number of operations that you can perform.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains two integers nn and mm (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105; 0≤m≤min(n(n−1)2,2⋅105)0≤m≤min(n(n−1)2,2⋅105)).

The ii-th of the following mm lines contains two integers xi,yixi,yi (1≤xi,yi≤n1≤xi,yi≤n; xi≠yixi≠yi) — the endpoints of the ii-th edge. There is at most one edge between each pair of vertices.
problems.outputSpecHtml: Output two integers — the minimum and the maximum number of operations.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first example, the shortest sequence of operations is as follows:

  • Choose vertices 11 and 33, then the resulting vertex will be connected to vertices 22, 44, 55, and there are no other vertices in the graph.

The longest sequence of operations is as follows:

  • Choose vertices 11 and 55. Let the resulting vertex be 66; it will not be connected to any of the remaining vertices.
  • Choose vertices 22 and 44. Let the resulting vertex be 77; it will be connected to vertex 33.
  • Choose vertices 77 and 33. Let the resulting vertex be 88; it will not be connected to any of the remaining vertices.
  • Choose vertices 66 and 88. Only one vertex will remain in the graph, so it will be connected to all other vertices.

In the second example, there is already a vertex in the graph that is connected to all others, so no operations can be performed.

In the third example, it will take 199999199999 operations to leave only one vertex in the graph, regardless of the approach.

problems.title: Color the Tree
problems.statementHtml:
You are given a tree consisting of nn vertices. Initially, none of the vertices of the tree are colored.

You can perform the following operation: choose any two vertices uu and vv (you are allowed to choose u=vu=v) and color all the vertices on the path between them (including the endpoints) with color ii, where ii is the index of the operation you are performing (that is, the first operation uses color 11, the second uses color 22, and so on). If any vertex on the path has already been colored before, its color changes to the new one.

We call the coloring of the tree complete if for each vertex, at least one operation has colored it.

Your task is to calculate two values:
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer nn (3≤n≤323≤n≤32) — the number of vertices in the tree.

The next (n−1)(n−1) lines contain two integers xixi and yiyi (1≤xi,yi≤n1≤xi,yi≤n; xi≠yixi≠yi) — the endpoints of the next edge of the tree.

Additional constraint on the input: the edges define a valid tree with nn vertices.
problems.outputSpecHtml: Print two integers — the minimum number of operations and the number of distinct complete colorings that can be obtained with the minimum number of operations. Since the second number can be very large, output it modulo 998244353998244353.

tutorial.contentHtml:
I hope you liked the problems! Thank you for participation. I am sorry that the difference between H and I turned out to be that big, I didn't expect that so many people would solve H.

The contest was prepared by me, Neon, adedalic, FelixArg and Roms. I would like to express my gratitude to the testers who helped us improve the contest: pashka, shnirelman and awoo.

See you in the next episode of Kotlin Heroes... sometime in the future (probably near the end of 2025).

2141A - Furniture Store

Idea: BledDest, preparation: Neon

Tutorial

2141A - Furniture Store

Observe that if there exists a model $$$j$$$ such that $$$j < i$$$ and $$$a_j < a_i$$$, no one will order the $$$i$$$-th model. Therefore, to solve the problem, we can iterate through the array, maintaining the minimum value on the prefix. If the next element is less than the minimum, then this model will be ordered. Otherwise, it must be included in the answer.

There is a more beautiful way to solve this problem, though it was not required. You can form an array of minimums on all prefixes of the given array (to do this, the function runningReduce can help; it also allows to make an array of prefix sums or most other functions on prefix). Then, a model can be ordered if and only if it is the minimum on its prefix; you can use filter to find those which are not minimums on the corresponding prefixes.
